questions.text: Correct sequence for disaster cycle is?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence for the disaster cycle is:

A. Mitigation → Preparedness → Response → Rehabilitation

This sequence follows the logical progression of disaster management:

  1. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the impact of potential disasters.
  2. Preparedness: Planning and preparation for potential disasters.
  3. Response: Immediate actions taken during and after a disaster.
  4. Rehabilitation: Recovery and rebuilding efforts after the disaster.

So, the correct answer is A.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The sequence for disaster cycle - Mitigation → Preparedness → Response → Rehabilitation

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-17, Page number.: 923-928.

questions.text: A 45 year old male was brought to the emergency department following road accident in a very bad condition, although his life was saved but unfortunately his foot got necrosed, so doctors had to perform an amputation operation, the removed foot will be discarded in which category of biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
The removed foot, being a human anatomical waste, should be discarded in the Yellow category of biomedical waste.

The Yellow category is used for waste that includes human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, and microbiological waste, which requires incineration or deep burial.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Human Anatomical waste is discarded in yellow bags.

Reference: Biomedical waste management rules, 2016 and amended 2018, https://clip.cpcb.gov.in/index.php/rule/bio-medical-waste-management-rules-2016/

questions.text: Level of serum lead for lead poisoning symptoms?
questions.solution:
Lead poisoning symptoms typically become apparent at serum lead levels greater than 70 mcg/dL (micrograms per deciliter). Therefore, the correct option is: c. >70 mcg/100ml

This unit is equivalent to 70 micrograms per deciliter, which is the standard measurement for serum lead levels.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Lead poisoning symptoms typically become apparent at serum lead levels greater than 70 mcg/dL (micrograms per deciliter).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-18, Page number.:940-943.

questions.text: A sudden earthquake hits Delhi area, there was loss of human life or deterioration of health, also loss of natural habitat. There were 300 people whose dead body was found. some had fracture, head injuries and some were hit a little bit as almost normal. for treatment bases all casualties are divided by the triage method, so according to the method in which category does the fractured patients are kept?
questions.solution:
In the triage method used during mass casualty incidents, patients with fractures (but who are not in immediate life-threatening conditions) are typically categorized as follows: d. Yellow

The Yellow category is for patients who have serious injuries that require medical attention but are not immediately life-threatening. They are in a stable condition and can wait for treatment.

The triage categories generally are:

  • Red: Immediate, life-threatening injuries requiring urgent treatment.
  • Yellow: Serious but not life-threatening injuries that require attention within a few hours.
  • Green: Minor injuries that are not urgent and can wait.
  • Black: Deceased or injuries so severe that survival is unlikely.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Fractured patients who need treatment but are not in immediate danger would be categorized under Yellow.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-17, Page number.:923-929.

questions.text: Following admission of a RTA case, there is spillage of blood on hospital floor. Which disinfectant will you use to clean the floor?
questions.solution:
For cleaning blood spills on a hospital floor, the most appropriate disinfectant is: d. Sodium hypochlorite

Sodium hypochlorite (bleach) is highly effective in disinfecting surfaces contaminated with blood and other bodily fluids. It is widely used in healthcare settings because it has strong bactericidal, virucidal, and fungicidal properties. It also helps to decontaminate the area and reduce the risk of transmission of infections.

Incorrect options:

  • Ethyl alcohol is effective for hand sanitization and smaller surfaces but may not be as effective for larger spills.
  • Chlorhexidine is used primarily for skin antisepsis and does not have the same efficacy for cleaning large surfaces contaminated with blood.
  • Formaldehyde is a strong disinfectant but is less commonly used for routine cleaning due to its potential health hazards and pungent odor.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: For cleaning blood spills on a hospital floor, the most appropriate disinfectant is: D. Sodium hypochlorite

Reference: Biomedical waste management rules, 2016 and amended 2018, https://clip.cpcb.gov.in/index.php/rule/bio-medical-waste-management-rules-2016/

questions.text: A known case of hepatitis B patient admitted to emergency ward with c/o severe pain in abdomen with fever. On investigation diagnosed as a case of acute cholecystitis with cholelithiasis. You had performed cholecystectomy how you are going to dispose off this removed gall bladder.
questions.solution:
For the disposal of a removed gall bladder from a patient with hepatitis B, the appropriate method is: a. Disinfection and incineration

  • Disinfection: The removed gall bladder should first be disinfected to minimize the risk of contamination and infection.
  • Incineration: After disinfection, incineration is the most effective method for safely disposing of biological materials, especially those potentially contaminated with infectious agents.

Incorrect Options:

  • Incineration (b) alone is appropriate but should follow disinfection to ensure the material is safely handled.
  • Land filling (c) is not suitable for biological materials as it poses a risk of infection and contamination.
  • Recycle (d) is not appropriate for biological waste due to health and safety risks.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Disinfection followed by incineration is the best practice for the safe disposal of such biological waste.

Reference: Biomedical waste management rules, 2016 and amended 2018, https://clip.cpcb.gov.in/index.php/rule/bio-medical-waste-management-rules-2016/

questions.text: A 40 year old factory worker, working in industry manufacturing fire proof textiles for past 10 years reported to medical OPD with c/o cough, shortness of breath. On investigation positive findings are- asbestos body in sputum, ground glass appearance on x ray. What could be possibility of dangerous condition?
questions.solution:
Given the patient's history of working in an industry involving asbestos and the clinical findings of asbestos bodies in sputum and ground glass appearance on X-ray, the most likely dangerous condition is: c. Bronchogenic carcinoma

  • Asbestos Exposure: Prolonged exposure to asbestos is a known risk factor for various respiratory conditions, including bronchogenic carcinoma (lung cancer).
  • Asbestos Bodies: These are indicative of asbestos exposure and can be associated with malignancies like lung cancer.
  • Ground Glass Appearance on X-ray: While this can be associated with several lung conditions, it can also indicate early stages of lung cancer or other asbestos-related diseases.

Differential diagnosis based on the patient's history and clinical findings:

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Findings of asbestos bodies in sputum and ground glass appearance on X-ray, the most likely dangerous condition is Bronchogenic carcinoma

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-18, Page number: 940-943.

questions.text: Causative organism of farmer's lung is?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of Farmer's Lung is: A. Micropolyspora faeni

Farmer's Lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhalation of dust containing Micropolyspora faeni and other thermophilic actinomycetes found in moldy hay, straw, and other agricultural products.

Farmer's Lung is a serious occupational hazard for agricultural workers.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Farmer's Lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhalation of dust containing Micropolyspora faeni and other thermophilic actinomycetes found in moldy hay, straw, and other agricultural products.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-18, Page number:940-945.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period?
questions.solution:
The disease that is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period is:A. Leishmaniasis

While diseases like Leptospirosis, Acute respiratory infections, and Rickettsial diseases can emerge due to factors such as contaminated water, overcrowding, and poor hygiene in post-disaster settings, Leishmaniasis typically spreads by sandflies and is more related to endemic areas rather than conditions immediately following a disaster.

Key Risk Factors in Post-Disaster Period:

  • Poor sanitation
  • Contaminated water
  • Overcrowding in shelters
  • Disruption of healthcare services
  • Increased exposure to vectors (e.g., mosquitoes, rats) due to environmental changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about reverse triage?
questions.solution:
The correct statement about reverse triage is:C. More injured victims are given the lowest preference

In reverse triage, the typical priority system is inverted.

This approach is used in mass casualty situations, especially in disaster settings, where medical resources are limited.

Patients with the most severe injuries, who are least likely to survive even with treatment, are given lower priority to allow medical care for those with less severe injuries who have a better chance of survival.

In standard triage, the highest preference is given to the most severely injured (red-coded), but reverse triage prioritizes those with the best chances of survival.

Reverse triage:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Reverse triage is a critical strategy in mass casualty situations to prioritize care based on survival probability rather than the severity of injuries alone.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-17,Page no.: 921-930.

questions.text: A nurse spilled blood on the floor. What can be used to disinfect it?
questions.solution:
To disinfect blood spills on the floor, the appropriate disinfectant is: 1% Sodium hypochlorite

Sodium hypochlorite, commonly known as bleach, is effective in disinfecting surfaces contaminated with blood and other potentially infectious materials. It is recommended for its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to inactivate a wide range of pathogens.

GUIDELINES FOR BLOOD SPILL MANAGEMENT

  • Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves.
  • Use tongs or a pan and brush to sweep up as much of the broken glass (or container) as possible. Do not pick up pieces with your hands.
  • Discard the broken glass in a sharps container. If this is not possible due to the size of the broken glass, wrap the glass or container in several layers of paper and discard it carefully in a separate container. Do not place it in the regular waste container.
  • Use disposable paper towels to absorb as much of the body fluids as possible.
  • Wipe the area with water and detergent until it is visibly clean.
  • Saturate the area again with sodium hypochlorite 5% (10 000 ppm available chlorine). This is a 1:10 dilution of 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach, which should be prepared daily.
  • Remove gloves and discard them.
  • Wash hands carefully with soap and water, and dry thoroughly with single-use towels.
  • Record the incident in the incident book if a specimen was lost, or persons were exposed to blood and body fluids.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Sodium hypochlorite, commonly known as bleach, is effective in disinfecting surfaces contaminated with blood and other potentially infectious materials. It is recommended for its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to inactivate a wide range of pathogens.

Reference: Biomedical waste management rules, 2016 and amended 2018,https://clip.cpcb.gov.in/index.php/rule/bio-medical-waste-management-rules-2016/
